title: Examining The Roots of Environmental Injustice in Minneapolis
text:
This interactive dashboard shows the legacy of residential segregation, one that has led to stark environmental injustice that tremendously ails Black, Latino, and Native American families in Minneapolis.
The correlation between climate change effects and marginalized neighborhoods are apparent: the more socially vulnerable a neighborhood is, the more exposed they are to the effects of climate change—and we can trace this back to residential seggregation practices from the early 20th century. Racial Covenants and Land Surface Temperature



The map shown on the right are racial covenants and mean land surface temperature map per census tract. As you can see that are with higher mean LST are in places with lower HOLC Grade and little to no racial covenants areas. Similarly, areas with higher HOLC Grade and with many racial covenants areas experience lower mean LST.








Racial Covenants and Social Vulnerability



Now the map shown on the right are racial covenants compared with air pollution map. Similarly to LST, you can see areas with higher annual PM2.5 are areas with low HOLC Grade, such as C and D, and places with little to no racial covenants








Racial Covenants and Air Pollution



Now the map shown on the right are racial covenants compared with social vulnerability map. You can see that places with higher social vulnerability index score are places with low HOLC Grade and places with little to no racial covenant areas.









As you can see, environmental injustices are deeply tied to historical segregation practices. To further study these patterns, we analyzed key numerical results:




Land Surface Temperature (LST):





On average, census tracts with higher social vulnerability had mean land surface temperatures that were 2.22°F higher than less vulnerable areas, even when controlling for tree canopy coverage.
The median of mean land surface temperature for socially vulnerable group is 95.78, and The median of mean land surface temperature for socially not vulnerable group is 93.78.











Annual Air Pollution:

On average, census tracts with higher social vulnerability had annual air pollution 0.97 tons than less vulnerable areas, even when controlling for tree canopy coverage.
The median of annual air pollution for socially vulnerable group is 1.597467 tons, and The median of mean land surface temperature for socially not vulnerable group is 1.013138 tons.

title: Racial Covenants
text:
Motivation
Black and Indigenous people in the U.S. are expected to “bear the brunt of the impact for the “greater good””. And there has been extensive research around environmental injustice, yet they tend to merely provide a snapshot of this picture at a moment in time. How can we contextualize and provide a comprehensive portrayal of this injustice?

title: Racial Covenants
text:
Research question
Looking at historically racially covenanted neighborhoods in Minneapolis and present day environmental data, can we still see patterns in the impact of residential seggregation on the disparity of climate change effects? In other words, how much does the introduction of racial covenants in the 1910s impact the environmental inequality in Minneapolis that we see today? How can we, then, inform environmental practices with data?

title: Examining The Roots of Environmental Injustice in Minneapolis
text:
Matching Analysis
We applied 5 We applied five matching methods to control for confounders and estimate the average treatment effect on the treated (ATT):

Nearest Neighbors (k=2)
Full Matching
Exact Matching
Coarsened Exact Matching
Subclass Matching

Among these, Exact Matching was chosen due to its superior balance (SMD = 0). However, this method resulted in a smaller matched sample size. Of the original 116 census tracts, only 97 observations were retained after matching, with 19 untreated tracts.

title: Examining The Roots of Environmental Injustice in Minneapolis
text:
Regression Analysis
We performed a regression analysis on the matched dataset to examine the relationship between land surface temperature (LST), social vulnerability (SVI), and tree canopy coverage. The regression model was as follows:
mod_lst <- lm(mean_lst ~ svi_index * tree_canopy_area, data = match_out_exact_data, weights = weights)
Results:

The average LST was 2.22°F higher in socially vulnerable neighborhoods, holding tree canopy coverage constant.
The interaction term between SVI and tree canopy area was statistically significant ((p = 0.007)), suggesting that the moderating effect of tree canopy on LST varies by social vulnerability.

What the Numbers Reveal
We analyzed the relationship between land surface temperatures, social vulnerability, and tree canopy coverage:

Socially vulnerable neighborhoods experience an average increase of 2.22°F in mean land surface temperature compared to less vulnerable areas.

title: Examining The Roots of Environmental Injustice in Minneapolis
text:
Why This Matters
Historical practices of residential segregation have left a lasting impact on environmental conditions. Marginalized communities are disproportionately exposed to higher temperatures, poorer air quality, and less green spaces.

Observations and Patterns
By examining the maps, we notice key patterns:


Neighborhoods with lower HOLC grades are associated with hotter mean land surface temperatures.


Areas with high air pollution levels and low tree canopy coverage are often socially vulnerable neighborhoods.


These insights highlight the intersection of historical practices and present-day environmental disparities.

title: Examining The Roots of Environmental Injustice in Minneapolis
text:
Regression Insights
To understand these patterns quantitatively, we used regression analysis to explore the relationship between social vulnerability, tree canopy coverage, and mean land surface temperatures.

Findings:

Socially vulnerable neighborhoods experience a 2.22°F increase in mean land surface temperature compared to less vulnerable areas, holding tree canopy constant.
Tree canopy significantly mitigates land surface temperatures, with higher coverage reducing the impact of social vulnerability.







Note



This underscores how historical practices of residential segregation continue to shape environmental conditions, exacerbating disparities in vulnerable communities.
